Buy a Minecraft server without monthly fees – how does that work?

To give “Minecraft Server Prices” as a term in the Google search, so are the terms “Rent Minecraft Server” and “Buy Minecraft servers’ – that’s what prompted us to pursue the question

“Can you actually buy a Minecraft server?”

When researching this article, we found that the term is often used for the purpose of SEO (search engine optimization) and that many “purchase offers” ultimately turned out to be normal rental offers or game server provider comparisons. Apparently, many players use the term “Minecraft Rent a server” with “buy” right there and the providers want to use this valuable traffic, of course. Many of these alleged “purchase offers” serve the purpose of ending up as early as possible in the corresponding Google search in order to bring visitors to their own site draw.

Buy Minecraft servers from ZAP-Hosting

The provider ZAP hosting*but is one of the rare game server providers who, in addition to the usual monthly rental offers for Minecraft servers, also offer to buy a Minecraft server.

Buying a Minecraft server – what exactly does that mean?

The idea behind it is to purchase a Minecraft server for a one-off price, which then costs no further monthly fees. In this way it would be possible to run a Minecraft project over a long period of time, possibly a few years, without having to worry about financing anymore. Nowadays it is quite easy to carry out a fundraising campaign via PAYPAL in order to get the 1x costs together.
Advertise on the home page ZAP hosting with the statement: “You pay once for your server and keep it for a lifetime, guaranteed without follow-up costs!” and “If you have enough money together, you pay for the one-time purchased Minecraft server and gamble – forever, without going over it again and again to discuss who will bear the server costs this month!”

Buy Minecraft Server 20 Slots, 2GB RAM, MySQL

Unfortunately, you don’t get any further details, neither what “for life” means nor further details about the Minecraft server you buy. Additional information can be provided during the ordering process, for example about the slots and the RAM memory that the server should have. Some links that are offered to answer questions lead to the normal rental offers. It is also unclear for the buyer that additional mods such as Bukkit or FTB are offered “optionally”. If you put such an offer in the shopping cart, nothing happens. Here, too, we suspect the purpose is more in the SEO area.
2 GB of RAM are included ZAP hosting* Default. We couldn’t understand why you also have to specify the number of slots, which then also costs additional (20 slots = 199 EUR). Especially since the entry-level configuration of 2GB RAM with 2 slots makes little sense for a lifetime server. Your own IP with standard port (EUR 69) and MySQL (EUR 49) also cost extra.

comparison configuration

For our comparison we used a Minecraft server with 2 GB RAM, 20 slots, MySQL database, standard port. This costs at ZAP hosting EUR 266 incl. VAT usable as a “purchase” without further costs.

Cost comparison buying Minecraft servers and renting Minecraft servers

We wanted to know “When is it worth buying and when is it better to rent a Minecraft server?” We compared the example configuration above with the rental prices from selected Minecraft providers for 6, 12, 24 and 36 months. Of course there are individual differences in the service provided by the providers and there can also be differences in performance. Since neither the rental offers for Minecraft servers nor the purchase offer make any further commitments with regard to performance, load behavior or the proportion of shared users per hardware server, we are making a pure cost comparison to determine the break-even point.

Break-Even for Minecraft Servers Buying vs. Renting

Conclusion buying vs. renting Minecraft servers
Our price comparison table brings it to the day. Even after 3 years (36 months) the purchase model has not yet broken even. The point at which buying a server is cheaper than renting it is not reached after 36 months, with many providers not even in 4 years. Not taken into account is the issue of flexibility, which you have with shorter terms, for example for a change of provider and other falling prices. Our conclusion therefore: Renting a Minecraft server is not worthwhile because it is too expensive compared to renting it.

As we at ZAP-Hosting* are now finding out, in addition to Minecraft servers for sale, they now also offer a very competitive range of rentable ones game servers on. The servers are billed fairly per slot. Then we have one right away Saving Coupon over 10% for you.
